required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Comparison of Visualization Between Shamrock Technique and Paramedian Transverse Scan in Lumbar Plexus Blockade
clinical_study.official_title: A Comparison of Visualization Between Shamrock Technique and Paramedian Transverse Scan in Lumbar Plexus Blockade

brief_summary.textblock: The primary objective of this study was to compare ultrasound visibility of the lumbar plexus at the intertransverse space between paramedian transverse scan and shamrock technique. Moreover obtaining a clear image of relevant structures is imperative. Thus, the secondary objective was to assess ultrasound visibility of each relevant structure and overall visibility between these two methods.

detailed_description.textblock:
Background: Ultrasound-guided lumbar plexus block (USG LPB) is regarded as a form of advanced ultrasound-guided regional anesthesia (USGRA). One of the key challenges of USG LPB is visualization of the lumbar plexus. That are currently in use for ultrasound-guided lumbar plexus blockade - paramedian transverse scan (PMTS) and shamrock technique.
Method: Twenty-three healthy adult volunteers aged â‰¥ 18 years were enrolled in this prospective cohort study. Ultrasound visualization results were compared between methods.

primary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Video (VDO) loops visualization of lumbar plexus
primary_outcome.description: Percentage of Video (VDO) loops visualization of lumbar plexus comparing between two techniques

secondary_outcome.measure: Ultrasound visibility score of each relevant structures
secondary_outcome.description: 10 structures: Erector spinae muscle, Quadratus lumborum muscle, Psoas muscle, Vertebral body, Inferior vena cava, Articular process of the lumbar vertebra, Lumbar paravertebral space, lumbar nerve root, Lumbar plexus nerve, Psoas compartment Using 4-point Likert scale (0, not visible; 1, hardly visible; 2, well visible; 3, very well visible)

secondary_outcome.measure: Overall ultrasound visibility score of 10 structures
secondary_outcome.description: Sum of ultrasound visibility score of 10 relevant structures: Erector spinae muscle, Quadratus lumborum muscle, Psoas muscle, Vertebral body, Inferior vena cava, Articular process of the lumbar vertebra, Lumbar paravertebral space, lumbar nerve root, Lumbar plexus nerve, Psoas compartment

arm_group.description: shamrock: both left and right sided scan,both intertransverse and transverse process window
paramedian transverse scan (PMTS): both left and right, both intertransverse and transverse process window

intervention.description: This scanning technique is performed in the lateral decubitus position with the side of interest facing upwards. The transducer is placed in the transverse plane on the flank of the patient cranially to the iliac crest. The quadratus lumborum muscle is identified medial to the aponeurosis of the transversus abdominis muscle. With the psoas muscle anterior to the transverse process, the erector spinae muscle posterior to the transverse process, and the quadratus lumborum muscle attached to the apex of the transverse process of L4.
The ultrasound transducer is positioned 4 cm lateral to the midline along the intercristal line and just above the iliac crest. The transducer is also directed slightly medially.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- healthy volunteer, age >/= 18
Exclusion Criteria:
- spinal deformity and history of previous back or spine surgery
